You know what's scary? Our report, Losing Our Minds: Brain Drain Across the United States, focuses on the extent to which states are losing their best-educated children. Read more about this frightening phenomenon:

"Rising living costs—paying more and more without getting more and more—naturally obstruct economic mobility. And they are among the obstacles to mobility for which public policy is most at fault, and could do the most to overcome." - Dr. Yuval Levin, @AEI

Q: Why is brain drain so worrisome? 
A: Economic growth is becoming more distinctive by region. Also, social segregation weakens the sentiment that, as Americans, we share something important in common with each other regardless of our other commitments. Learn more 👇🏼

"Social policy often forgets that people are better when they are in communities... that extend across different realms of their lives. And if we had that mind when we develop social policy then we have a much better chance of building stronger communities." @patrick_sharkey

Far from affecting only politics, social segregation reduces social cohesion and trust. It leaves behind communities with crumbling institutions of civil society. It also impedes the development of the social wealth that flows from relationships connecting dissimilar communities.
In his 2008 book, The Big Sort, Bill Bishop makes the case that Americans are increasingly dividing themselves into communities of like-minded individuals. This has exacerbated political divisions.

The clustering of the highly-educated into major metropolitan areas is part of what some researchers argue is a larger geographical division by self-selection that has been taking place in the United States.

Brain drain is creating a “new urban crisis” of class segregation. “Winner-take-all cities,” such as #LosAngeles, #NewYork, #SanFrancisco, #Chicago, and #Boston, claim a disproportionate share of highly-educated Americans. Americans with less education are often left behind. pic.twitter.com/QzDx2en4Qt

There appears to be a growing geographic divide in the United States between talent magnets and communities left behind. 
These states are some of the best talent magnets 👇🏼 https://twitter.com/JECRepublicans/status/1187363222736822272?s=20 …

Brain drain has become an economic concern for state & local policymakers in recent decades. States that fail to retain the most-skilled of those born within their borders—or fail to replace them by attracting the most-skilled from other states—are at risk of economic stagnation.

Gross vs Net brain drain: Gross is the share of leavers who are highly educated minus the share of adults who remain in their birth state who are highly educated. Net is the share of leavers who are highly educated minus the share of entrants to a state who are highly educated.
We define a highly-educated “leaver” as someone in the top third of the national education distribution who resides in a state other than her birth state between the ages of 31 and 40.
This phenomenon has far-reaching implications for our collective social and political life, extending beyond the economic problems for states that lose highly-educated adults.

Over the decades, the US has experienced major shifts in geographic mobility patterns among its highly-educated citizens. Some states are keeping/receiving more of these adults, while many others are hemorrhaging their homegrown talent and failing to attract out-of-staters. ⬇️

It shows the progress that has been made in inequality measurement and the considerable challenges that remain. For those interested in the current controversy over measuring national income concentration, it also addresses the disagreements that are unresolved. Check it out ⬆️

This primer is intended to address the debate around income concentration specifically. It reviews the academic debates around how much income goes to the “top one percent,” conveying how we have arrived at the present:  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?id=A8EB0668-F0FD-4CD4-BE7B-CE3FABE0FEB0 … pic.twitter.com/jfC6KwbMBt

“Rather than focusing on making the top end of the distribution worse off, policymakers should consider a robust growth agenda for raising the incomes of those at and near the bottom.” - @djheakin Watch the rest below ⬇️

The question of who is right in these debates hinges on a variety of technical measurement questions & assumptions and the quality of various data sources. The debates have become inaccessible to even many observers with considerable economic training. 3/3

But other researchers have reported modestly rising income inequality, growth in wealth inequality that is less sharp, rising tax progressivity, and more robust income growth for lower-income Americans. 2/3
ICYMI: The work of Piketty, Saez, and Zucman suggests sharply rising income and wealth inequality, falling tax progressivity, and stagnant income growth for the bottom half of Americans... 1/3

It's simply inappropriate at this stage to make strong claims about the trend of income concentration, without heavy caveats. It is inappropriate to justify preferred policies on the basis of national income distribution figures and tax distribution figures that are contested.

But other researchers have reported modestly rising income inequality, growth in wealth inequality that is less sharp, rising tax progressivity, and more robust income growth for lower-income Americans.
The work of Piketty, Saez, and Zucman suggests sharply rising income and wealth inequality, falling tax progressivity, and stagnant income growth for the bottom half of Americans.

Q: Is America in the middle of a loneliness epidemic?
A: 👇🏼
ICYMI: The September #JobsReport shows that the employment to population ratio for prime age workers continues to rise. pic.twitter.com/QQWdhCxpj2

Keep up on the latest news from the Joint Economic Committee and the Social Capital Project by signing up for the JEC newsletter! Sign up or view past newsletters here:  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/subscribe … pic.twitter.com/trIQzIl3Yr

We will need new data if we want to compare today’s loneliness levels to those of the past. Unless we ask survey respondents the same questions that were asked in past surveys, we will never know whether loneliness is on the rise.

Loneliness is certainly a problem for whom it chronically persists, and it might be a problem in the United States generally, but the first order of business must be understanding the scale and characteristics of the challenge.

The loneliness discussion has suggested to media consumers and policymakers that it has increased substantially and is a pressing problem. 
These claims are based on a flawed interpretation of the research literature. There is little evidence that loneliness has increased.

ICYMI: September's #JobsReport is out.
The American economy continues to thrive and reach new milestones. The unemployment rate fell to a 50-year low of 3.5%. pic.twitter.com/bI3RhVA8Dx
The labor market continues to break recent records. For instance, the unemployment rate has fallen to a 50-year low! #JobsReport pic.twitter.com/vwHAMXO5CO

Fischer points out that headlines from major newspapers trumpeted the findings of a 2006 paper. Over several years, many of the study's headline-grabbing claims—often used to support a narrative of increasing loneliness—were found less sturdy than they initially seemed. pic.twitter.com/7nHJ17X2VC

The single best data-intensive look at the question of rising loneliness is Claude S. Fischer’s Still Connected. He concludes that although there has been great change over the decades, we have adapted to those changes and are probably no less connected today than 50 years ago. pic.twitter.com/4t9z3jX6Yk

The available evidence does not appear to support the claim that #loneliness has increased substantially since the 1980s. It is just as possible that loneliness has stayed the same or even declined. https://twitter.com/JECRepublicans/status/1179109117274796033 …

Last week, @AEI released a report on how marriage, religion, and mobility explain the generation gap in loneliness. 
Read about it here:  https://www.aei.org/research-products/report/loneliness-epidemic-how-marriage-religion-and-mobility-explain-the-generation-gap-in-loneliness/ … pic.twitter.com/psSUcHK3hc

It is entirely possible that loneliness has increased over time, but the available evidence does not appear to support that claim. It is just as possible that loneliness has stayed the same or even declined.

The claim that loneliness has doubled since the 1980s is hard to substantiate. The polling questions through the decades are all different from each other. The threshold for being "lonely" also varies by study. This inconsistency raises questions of reliability.
These estimates are hardly conclusive evidence that loneliness has been mostly stable since the early 1960s, but they cast significant doubt on the claim that it has risen significantly.

***Caveats: [1] It’s unwise to assess trends using data points from different polling organizations, which have their own methods. [2] Current events may have affected the NORC polls. The 1963 poll was conducted just after JFK’s assassination; the 2001 poll shortly after 9/11.

In 1985 and 2000, Harris polls found that respondents' experience of loneliness in the past month did not rise over the period, remaining under 20% in both years. Between 1963 and 2001, NORC surveys show a slight decline in reported feelings of loneliness, from 28 to 25%. pic.twitter.com/xPWL4wWyfw
From reading the headlines, one would certainly get the impression that loneliness is increasing. However, it is not at all clear that loneliness has increased over the last several decades.

One important question is whether Americans are increasingly alone (have fewer social contacts or less social interaction). Another question is whether Americans are increasingly experiencing loneliness ("perceived social isolation").

It’s hard to define loneliness. 
Some define it as "perceived social isolation." Others as "the distressing feeling that accompanies discrepancies between one's desired and actual social relationships." pic.twitter.com/nqbbWzgpc5
